results.title: La Quete de Dieu
results.brief_description:
In a world almost empty of population and surrounded by the constant fear of war or invasion, small groups of people manage to erect magnificent churches. Northern Europe dominated by the heirs of Charlemagne lives the second blooming of classical Roman art. In the South, on the other side of the Loire river and the Alps, the culture and the landscapes are different. There is no central power or emmerging feudal system. The centre of power is the monastry where various experiments lead to a marked improvement in vaulting techniques. In the XIth century, religious buildings are built by paid labourers (the future guilds) but designed by clerics, “men both erudite and initiated into the mysteries. For them, considerations of perfect knowledge were to be found in numbers. And the highest human science was mathematics, closely linked to music and architecture. A romanesque church is at the same time an equation and a fugue.” Other works profiled include: the abbey of Conques (France) and the manuscripts of Gerona (Spain).

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: La Quebecoise
results.creator_credit: Les Nirenberg, Ian McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Her image has changed. The French-Canadian woman of today is no longer the chattel of yesterday, without legal rights and with limited career opportunuites. Speaking of the struggle to bring about change, the evolving role of women in Quebec society, and the challenges still ahead are some very articulate ladies: Senator Therese Casgrain, Judge Rejane Colas, a nun, a Playboy bunny, and seveal feminists.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Les Nirenberg, Ian McLaren and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: La Proie Pour L'ombre = Shadow of Adultery (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
The wife of a rich building contractor, beginning to tire of being merely a social asset to her husband, finds an outlet by running an art gallery and taking a lover. In the end, she sacrifices both men for her independence. White sports cars, cocktail parties, an art gallery, a recording studio, modern skyscrapers, jazz and Bach on the soundtrack and quick, slick cross-cutting, give Astruc’s contribution to the ‘Nouvelle Vague’ an over-riding air of chic. In this film Astruc is also influenced by Japanese filmmaker Mizoguchi (‘Tales of a Pale Moon After the Rain’) for whom he had great admiration.

Credits: Producer, Leopold Schlosberg ; director, Alexandre Astruc ; writers, Alexandre Astruc, Claude Brule ; photography, Marcel Grignon ; music, Richard Cornu, Jean-Sebastien Bach ; art direction ; Jacques Saulnier.
Cast: Annie Girardot, Christian Marquand, Daniel Gelin, Michele Girardon, Michele Gerbier.

results.title: La Prise du Pouvoir Par Louis XIV = The Rise of Louis XIV
results.brief_description:
At the death of Cardinal Mazarin in 1661, Louis XIV, seconded by Colbert, imposes to France his concept of absolute monarchy. It is as if a documentary cameraman had been let loose in the royal court of the 17th century Sun King. The use of unfamiliar actors in the major roles adds to the film’s realism. Though shown to be the product of a decadent lifestyle, Louis is depicted as being trapped by his royalty, forced in spite of himself to be a raconteur and trendsetter. ‘The Rise of Louis XIV’ was one of several innovative films directed for French television by Roberto Rossellini.

Credits: Director, Roberto Rossellini ; writers, Philippe Erlanger, Jean Gruault ; photography, Georges Leclerc.
Cast: Jean-Marie Patte, Raymond Jourdan, Silvagni, Katharina Renn.

results.title: La Poursuite = Just a King's Second (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Francois Leterrier, Andree Debar and Jean Giono
results.brief_description:
In 1840, a young captain of the Gendarmerie is called by a retired lawyer to investigate the disappearance of a young girl from a mountain village. Once there, other crimes are committed and the captain starts to suspect that the ‘murderer’ might simply be after a way to fight boredom. Awards: Grand Prix du Cinema Francais 1963.

Credits: Producers, Jean Giono, Andree Debar ; director, Francois Leterrier
Cast: Claude Giraud, Colette Renard, Charles Vanel, Pierre Repp.

results.title: La Poulette grise (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Presentation in cartoon form by Norman McLaren of an old French-Canadian folk song. Anna Malenfant sings the traditional French-Canadian song about the little grey hen who nests in the moon, the words of the song being illustrated by animated forms.

results.title: La Poulette grise
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A Norman McLaren lullaby on film about the little grey hen who nests in the church, the little brown hen who nests in the moon, and others. Photographed from pastel drawings, the transient images express the dreamy mood of this old French song.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: La Pointe-Courte
results.brief_description: A penetrating study of a marriage on the rocks, set against the backdrop of a small Mediterranean fishing village. Both a stylized depiction of the complicated relationship between a married couple and a documentary-like look at the daily struggles of the inhabitants of Sète in the South of France.

constellations_other.name: All about Agnes
constellations_other.description: Belgian director Agnes Varda was the only female director in the French New Wave movement and is known for her long career across influential documentary and dramas, and for her trademark humour, curiosity and insight.

results.description: A penetrating study of a marriage on the rocks, set against the backdrop of a small Mediterranean fishing village. Both a stylized depiction of the complicated relationship between a married couple and a documentary-like look at the daily struggles of the inhabitants of Sète in the South of France.

results.title: La Peau et les Os = Skin and Bone
results.creator_credit: Jean-Paul Sassy, Rene Thevenet and Rene Bezard
results.brief_description:
While in prison, Jacques encounters the hostility of the other inmates who suspect him to be a snitch. A sudden reversal of situation gives him an opportunity to acquire both prestige and the trust of his companions. Ather this incident, inmates band together to help prove his innocence. Jacques finds himself free, without knowing to whom he owns his freedom. Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1961.

Credits: Producers, Rene Bezard, Rene Thevenet; director, Jean-Paul Sassy ; writers, Jacques Panijel, Jean-Paul Sassy ; photography, Georges Leclerc ; music, Louiguy ; art direction, Sydney Bettex.
Cast: Gerard Blain, Juliette Mayniel, Andre Oumansky, Rene Dary, Julien Verdier, Etienne Bierry.

results.title: La partria o la tumba
results.brief_description: Socialist parents, rebellious children - it runs in the blood. Esteban’s parents originally came from Uruguay but were forced to flee to Australia in 1974 from the ruling military regime. His father, aged 32, and mother, aged 21, eventually settled in Melbourne raising four children and establishing the first South American bakery, in Yarraville. In this story, Esteban talks of his family’s experiences and his deep respect for his wonderful rebellious parents.
